awd_titl_txt: Ice Storm Risk Workshop; West Lafayette, Indiana; October 11-12, 2021
awd_abstract_narration:
Ice storms pose significant risks to infrastructure, transportation, forests, and the economy, with annual losses in the billions of dollars.  The basic weather patterns that result in ice storms are well-understood, however there are questions about how well ice storms are represented in climate models and how ice storm risk may change in a future climate.  This award is for a small workshop to be held at Purdue University that will bring together meteorological experts with risk experts from a number of industries to define the high priority research questions that the atmospheric science field should be addressing in the upcoming years.  The workshop has direct societal relevance due to the long-term goal of improving forecasting and reducing ice storm risks.

This award is for a two-day Ice Storm Risk Workshop to explore scientific questions and risk mitigation for freezing rain events.  The meeting will take place on campus at Purdue University on October 11-12, 2021.  The central objective of the workshop is to generate an interdisciplinary road map of critical research gaps in ice storm science and risk, with specific focus to: 1) define solutions for reducing ice storm risks under climate change; and 2) identify the underlying scientific knowledge gaps that must be filled to realize those solutions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In October 2021, Purdue University hosted the Purdue Ice Storm Risk Workshop, a 2-day workshop bringing together over 40 experts from across weather and climate science and a wide range of sectors impacted by freezing rain. Participants came from both academia and practitioners across meteorology, climate, aviation, energy, agriculture, forestry, and economics. The workshop was funded jointly by this NSF grant and a seed grant from the Purdue Climate Change Research Center. The organizing team was comprised of 6 faculty members at Purdue University across Earth, Atmospheric, and Planetary Sciences, Forestry and Natural Resources, and Ecological and Environmental Engineering.

 

The workshop was held virtually through zoom and was facilitated professionally by Divergent Science and Lean To Collaborations. Initial planning for the workshop began in 2019 with a target date of May 2020, but was postponed twice due to the Covid-19 pandemic. Eventually the team decided to retain the October 2021 date and shift to a virtual format to ensure the event took place despite ongoing Covid-related complications. Participants used the interactive software platform Mural to facilitate interaction, ideation, collaboration, and synthesis of information. On Day 1, workshop facilitators led the group through open brainstorming sessions and breakout discussion groups to broaden the horizons of everyone involved. On Day 2, facilitators led the group back together to consolidate ideas that emerged from the prior day?s ideation process, to identify the lowest-hanging fruit directions that would help reduce real-world freezing rain risks, and to identify leaders for each of those directions. Professional workshop facilitation, whose cost was covered by this NSF grant, was essential to a successful workshop especially given the difficult virtual environment.

 

Key outcomes of the workshop were: 1) Catalysis of a new network of researchers coming from highly diverse backgrounds interested in all facets of freezing rain science and impacts under climate change; 2) Identification of four most critical directions for future collaboration to advance understanding of freezing rain and increase resilience. The critical directions are: 1) Evaluate the skill of forecast models to represent and predict freezing rain amounts and causes of biases; 2) Increase dialogue between on-the-ground decision-makers and weather/climate scientists to ensure decision-relevant science questions are being answered; 3) Develop a coherent database of key freezing rain quantities relevant to risk (e.g. accretion) from both public and private sources; 4) Synthesis of geography of historical (present day) freezing rain risks across sectors and forecasting limitations that modulate this risk. These critical needs can greatly improve our surprisingly limited understanding of freezing rain meteorology and impacts today, which is needed to understand how these impacts will change under climate change.
